a.commentary: In common usage (both before and after pu), "a" and "kin" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms.

akesi.commentary: akesi used to mean "non-cute animal," and is defined this way in pu, but this definition has fallen out of use and was later removed in the pu annotations published with ku.

alasa.commentary: The usage of "alasa" as a preverb meaning "try to" is more common than "lukin". In pu, only "lukin" has this meaning.
alasa.etymology: à la chasse: fub(p)bap(p)bus(p)fuf(t)sol(t)bop(p)ga(f) gin(t)​vek(t)​bis(f)​sub(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), hunting, (literally) on the hunt

ale.commentary:
"ali" is an alternative to "ale", coined in a poll in 2002 in order to avoid confusion with "ala". However, the usage of "ale" over "ali" remains more common.
The majority of speakers report not understanding the "abundant, bountiful, plentiful" meaning, at least out of context.
"20, 120" were non-pu meanings previously in use in the community alongside 100; they are virtually unheard of nowadays.
ale.definition: all, every, everything, entirety, universe; (number) one hundred

ali.commentary: "ali" is an alternative to "ale", coined in a poll in 2002 in order to avoid confusion with "ala". However, the usage of "ale" over "ali" has been more common since at least the release of pu. Generally not considered a word in its own right.

anpa.commentary: In common usage (both before and after pu), "anpa" has the meaning of "place that is down". In pu, "noka" has that meaning instead.
anpa.definition: bottom, underside; below, beneath; defeated, humble, lowly

ante.definition: different, altered; modify, change; other; difference

anu.commentary: The usage of "anu" as a content word meaning "choose" remains controversial.
anu.definition: (particle) [separates multiple possibilities, replacing another particle], or

apeja.commentary: According to jan Sonja, "apeja" never appeared in any pre-pu toki pona dictionary made by her and never promoted by her, instead it may have been "just an experimental idea in a forum post".
apeja.definition: guilt, shame, shun, stigma, disgrace; to accuse, to single out, to expose, to dishonor, to embarrass

awen.definition: stay, remain, wait, pause; protect, keep safe; continue; (preverb) continue to
awen.etymology: houden: pil(f)​sesh(p)​fol(p)​bef(f)​bok(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), keep, care for, hold (in a particular state)

e.definition: (particle) [marks the start of a direct object]

en.commentary: There are various analyses of the syntactic role of "en". Originally intended to be used as "and", it was changed (via poll in 2002) to just be used with "head nouns". One of the more recent analyses (including 2021's April Fools) treats "en" as a subject marker.

esun.commentary: According to jan Sonja, "esun was told [to her] by a taxi driver who spoke a language from the Akan family in West Africa".
esun.definition: trade, barter, exchange, swap, buy, sell; market, shop, fair, bazaar, place of business

ijo.definition: thing, object, entity, being, matter, phenomenon
ijo.etymology: io: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), something; i-: Romance, (relative pronoun root)

ike.definition: negative quality, e.g. bad, unpleasant, harmful, unneeded

insa.definition: inside, center, between, middle, midpoint, internal
insa.etymology: insait: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), inside, center, stomach; inside: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), inside

isipin.definition: to think, brainstorm, rationalize, conclude, ponder

jaki.definition: disgusting, unclean, unsanitary, toxic, repulsive, rotten

jami.definition: yummy; eliciting or stimulating a positive sensory experience

jan.commentary: There are two sides to the concept, "sentient entity" and "homo sapiens", which matters for whether to use the word in edge cases (i.e. aliens, humans turned into werewolves, etc). Which sense is more central to the word remains controversial.

jelo.commentary: Some extend "jelo" to include lime green, but this usage is uncommon.
jelo.definition: yellow, amber, golden, lime yellow, yellowish orange

kala.definition: fish, marine animal, sea creature, swimming creature

kalama.definition: to produce sound; sound, e.g. sing, thunder, drum, clap, laugh, beep
kalama.etymology: галама (galama): Serbo-Croatian, noise (of the human voice)

kama.definition: arriving, coming, future, summoned; (preverb) to become, manage to, succeed in
kama.etymology: kamap: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), event, arrive, happen, become, bring about, summon

kamalawala.commentary: The word is from a story called "jan pi Kamalawala". A character's name is described as "nimi Jan pi Kama e Lawa Ala", and a shortened version given as "nimi Kamalawala". jan Kipo is responsible for it becoming a word instead of just a name.
kamalawala.etymology: kama pi lawa ala: kay(f)​to(t)ki(t)po(t)na(t)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​ngag(t)​vlim(p)​kay(f)​sna(f)​yup(f)​a(f), 'arrival of no government', the beginning of anarchy

kapesi.etymology: 咖啡色 (gaa³ fe¹ sik¹): kay(f)​粵(f)​語(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), brown, coffee (colour); 咖啡色 (kāfēisè): seb(t)pof(p)pas(f)pis(p)ga(f) lab(b)​lik(f)​pav(f)​mal(p)​fof(b)​bot(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), brown, coffee (colour)

ken.definition: can, may, ability, permission; possibility, maybe; allow, enable; (preverb) to be able to

kepeken.commentary: Whether "kepeken" should be used with or without "e" in a predicative position (meaning "to use") remains controversial.

kijetesantakalu.commentary: Coined as an April Fools joke in 2009.
kijetesantakalu.definition: raccoon, kinkajou; any procyonid; any musteloid

kiki.commentary: The word is loaned from the 2001 Vilanyur S Ramachandran & Edward Hubbard version of Wolfgang Köhler's 1912 psycholinguistic experiment. The experiment studied sound symbolism on the words "bouba" and "kiki".

kili.commentary: In post-ku 2021, metaphorical definitions for kili have been suggested, including but not limited to "offspring" and "product", and are moderately popular. It is not yet clear whether this will remain in use long-term.

kin.commentary:
In common usage (both before and after pu), "a" and "kin" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms.
Underwent significant changes in usage in 2002, alongside "en" and (now obsolete) "kan".
kin.definition: (particle) [after phrase or at sentence start] too, also, as well, additionally

kipisi.definition: split, cut, slice; piece, part; sharp, pointy

kiwen.commentary: This word was coined in a poll in 2002, replacing the compound phrase "wawa ma".
kiwen.definition: hard object e.g. metal, stone, wood

ko.commentary: The "clinging form" definition was elaborated to mean "a shape or mass that sticks or clings; a clot, a thick or viscous lump, a clump that can be reshaped".
ko.definition: semi-solid, e.g. paste, powder, goo, sand, soil, clay; squishy, moldable; sticky

kokosila.commentary: In Esperanto, "krokodili" means "to speak among Esperantists in a language besides Esperanto," and is an established bit of Esperanto culture.
kokosila.definition: to speak a non-Toki Pona language in an environment where Toki Pona is more appropriate
kokosila.etymology: krokodilas: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), to speak among Esperantists in a language other than Esperanto; krokodilo: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), crocodile

kon.definition: air, breath, wind; essence, spirit, soul, ghost; unseen agent
kon.etymology: 空氣 (kōngqì): seb(t)pof(p)pas(f)pis(p)ga(f) lab(b)​lik(f)​pav(f)​mal(p)​fof(b)​bot(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), air, atmosphere, ambience, opinion

konwe.commentary:
Conway refers to John Horton Conway, creator of the cellular automaton Game of Life.
konwe's intended meaning extends beyond just "living" and "life." It can be used to describe rocks or rivers or other nonliving things
konwe.definition: animacy, life, autonomy; autonomous being, living thing, organism; alive, animate, dynamic; to animate, to bring to life
konwe.etymology: Conway: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), John Conway, creator of The Game of Life; kon wile: kay(f)​to(t)ki(t)po(t)na(t)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​ngag(t)​vlim(p)​kay(f)​sna(f)​yup(f)​a(f), kon wile

ku.commentary: For ways to buy a copy of the book, visit the official Toki Pona website.
ku.definition: interacting with the book Toki Pona Dictionary (2021) by Sonja Lang

kule.commentary: in addition to its pu-definitions, kule is sometimes used to talk about more general kinds of categories, like type, kind, flavour, gender, etc.
kule.definition: color, pigment; category, genre, flavor; colorful, diverse

kulijo.definition: (interjection) [casually express appreciation or acknowledgement]; cool, fine, okay

kulupu.definition: group, community, society, company, nation, collection, team, crowd

kute.definition: ear, hearing organ; hear, listen, pay attention to, obey

la.definition: (particle) [mark the previous statement as context to the following statement]
la.etymology: la: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), (definite article); la: Romance, (feminine singular definite article); -la: fub(p)bap(p)bus(p)fuf(t)sol(t)bop(p)ga(f) gin(t)​vek(t)​bis(f)​sub(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), (proximal & topical suffix)

lanpan.etymology: λαμβάνω (lamváno): Greek, take, seize, grasp, receive

lape.definition: sleep, rest, break from an activity or work

laso.definition: turquoise, blue, green, cyan, indigo, lime green
laso.etymology: glas: Welsh, blue, inexperienced; glas: Proto-Brythonic, green, blue

lawa.definition: head, mind, brain; control, lead, guide; government, leader; rule, law

leko.definition: square, cube, block, blocky object e.g. bricks, stairs
leko.etymology: Lego: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), Lego; leg godt: Danish, play well; lohko: sul(b)​rad(b)​sib(f)​fuf(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), block, section

len.definition: cloth, clothing, fabric, textile; covered, hidden, secret, private

lete.definition: cold, cool, frozen; freeze, chill; raw, uncooked
lete.etymology: frette: fub(p)bap(p)bus(p)fuf(t)sol(t)bop(p)ga(f) gin(t)​vek(t)​bis(f)​sub(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), cold; freit: Old French, cold

li.definition: (particle) [marks the start of an indicative verb (statement)]
li.etymology: li: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), he; ille: Latin, he; i: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), he; he: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), he

lili.definition: small, short, young; few; piece, part
lili.etymology: liklik: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), small, little; liklik: Ramoaaina, small, little

linja.definition: long, flexible thing, e.g. rope, yarn, hair, fur, line, strand
linja.etymology: linja: sul(b)​rad(b)​sib(f)​fuf(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), line; linia: Old Swedish, line

linluwi.definition: bonded things which are stronger through their bonds e.g. network, internet, connection; weave, braid, interlace

lipu.definition: flat and bendable object, e.g. paper, card, leaf; written text or document, e.g. book, website, clay tablet

loje.definition: red, magenta, scarlet, pink, rust-colored, reddish orange

lon.definition: present, existing, real, true; (preposition) located at, in, during, in the context of
lon.etymology: long: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), at, in, on, (spacial particle); along: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), along

luka.definition: hand, arm, tactile limb, grasping limb; to grasp, interact with, feel using touch; (number) five

lukin.commentary: In common usage (both before and after pu), "lukin" and "oko" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms. Those who consider them synonyms typically don't use "oko" at all, preferring "lukin" in all circumstances. The usage of "alasa" as a preverb meaning "try to" is more common than "lukin". In pu, only "lukin" has this meaning. A very common beginner mistake is treating "lukin" as if it means "appearance", due to the mistakenly equating the "visual" meaning as in "pona lukin (visually good)" to mean "looks good".
lukin.definition: see, look, view, examine, read, watch; visual; eye, seeing organ; (preverb) try to
lukin.etymology: lukim: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), see, look at; look: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), look; him: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), him

lupa.definition: hole, pit, cave, doorway, window, portal
lupa.etymology: clupa: Lojban, loop; 圈 (quān): seb(t)pof(p)pas(f)pis(p)ga(f) lab(b)​lik(f)​pav(f)​mal(p)​fof(b)​bot(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), loop; loop: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), loop; पाश (pāś): Hindi, loop; أنشوطة‏ (anšūṭa): Arabic, loop

ma.definition: earth, land, soil; country, territory, world; outdoors

majuna.etymology: maljuna: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), old (not young); malus: Latin, bad; jung: pup(b)​seb(f)​val(f)​tep(p)​bof(b)​zhel(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), young; jeune: gin(t)​vek(t)​bis(f)​sub(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), young

mama.definition: parent, ancestor; creator, originator; caretaker, sustainer, guardian

mani.definition: money, currency; thing of value e.g. gold, investment, livestock
mani.etymology: money: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), money; fehu: Proto-Germanic, livestock; pecū: Latin, cattle

meli.definition: woman, female, feminine person, wife, girlfriend
meli.etymology: meri: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), woman, wife, feminine; mari: Tolai, pretty; Mary: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), Mary

melome.etymology: meli pi olin meli: kay(f)​to(t)ki(t)po(t)na(t)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​ngag(t)​vlim(p)​kay(f)​sna(f)​yup(f)​a(f), women loving women

meso.definition: midpoint, medium, mediocre; neither one not the other, neither fully is nor isn't

mi.etymology: mi: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), I, me; m-: Romance, (1st person singular oblique)

mije.definition: man, male, masculine person, husband, boyfriend

mijomi.etymology: mije pi olin mije: kay(f)​to(t)ki(t)po(t)na(t)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​ngag(t)​vlim(p)​kay(f)​sna(f)​yup(f)​a(f), men loving men

misa.definition: Glires or Eulipotyphla; rat, mouse, squirrel, rabbit, rodent; {~ suli} capybara

misikeke.commentary: The word was used privately by jan Sonja up until November 2019, when she mentioned it in the ma pona pi toki pona discord server as a word she was experimenting with. It is believed the word was originally coined in 2007-2009 alongside pan, esun, apeja, monsuta, and pu, but this cannot be proven.
misikeke.definition: medical item or practice e.g. prescriptions, meditation, exercise, bandages, therapy

moku.definition: eat, drink, consume, swallow, ingest; food, edible thing

moli.definition: death, dead, die, dying; kill, murder

monsuta.definition: fear, nervousness, dread; scary, frightening; scary thing e.g. predator, threat, danger
monsuta.etymology: モンスター (monsutā): pov(t)​luw(f)​mi(p)​vu!(b)​luf(p)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), monster; monster: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), monster

mun.definition: moon, night sky object, star, celestial body

musi.definition: fun, game, entertainment, art, play, amusing, interesting, comical, silly
musi.etymology: amuzi: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), amuse, entertain; amuser: gin(t)​vek(t)​bis(f)​sub(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), amuse, entertain

mute.etymology: multe: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), a lot; multus: Latin, a lot

n.definition: (interjection) hm, uh, mm, er, umm, [indicate thinking or pause]

namako.commentary: In common usage (both before and after pu), "sin" and "namako" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms. Those who consider them synonyms typically don't use "namako" at all, preferring "sin" in all circumstances.
namako.etymology: नमक (namak): Hindi, salt; نمک (namak): Persian, salt

nasa.definition: strange, unusual, silly, abnormal, unexpected; drunk, intoxicated

nasin.definition: method, doctrine, tradition; path, road, way

nena.definition: protuberances e.g. bump, button, hill, nose

ni.etymology: 呢 (ni): kay(f)​粵(f)​語(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), this; 哩 (le): Tai, (continuation of a state/action)

nimisin.commentary: Mostly used in conversations in English. Likely was popularised by the :nimisin: emote in ma pona, which was originally used to notify Atawan (maintainer of "nimi ale") about newly coined words. In common speech, the meaning got extended to include most or all non-pu words, regardless if they were coined recently or not.
nimisin.definition: any non-pu word; any new word; any joke word

noka.commentary: noka can also mean any action involving the foot or leg, e.g. to kick, to step on, to touch with the leg.
noka.definition: foot, leg, organ of locomotion, roots

o.definition: (particle) [marks the end of a vocative (who is being spoken to)], [marks the start of an imperative (command, wish, instruction)], should

ojuta.definition: adaptation of the English meme "ligma", (literally) "o uta" (lick)
ojuta.etymology: o uta: kay(f)​to(t)ki(t)po(t)na(t)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​ngag(t)​vlim(p)​kay(f)​sna(f)​yup(f)​a(f), 'lick my balls' (same as English 'ligma balls')

oko.commentary: In common usage (both before and after pu), "lukin" and "oko" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms. Those who consider them synonyms typically don't use "oko" at all, preferring "lukin" in all circumstances, though some speakers do the opposite and use "oko" exclusively instead.
oko.definition: see, look, view, examine, read, watch; visual; eye, seeing organ; (preverb) try to

olin.commentary: In english, "love" can be used to mean "like a lot", but in toki pona, "olin" doesn't work that way. It indicates an emotional connection or bond, not preference
olin.definition: to have a strong emotional bond with, e.g. affection, appreciation, compassion, respect; platonic, romantic, or familial relationships

omekapo.commentary: Coined by jan Maliku in reference to the message "o moku e kala pona", which jan Sonja wrote on their copy of Toki Pona: The Language of Good during a Texas meetup.
omekapo.definition: goodbye, farewell, see you later, (literally) "o moku e kala pona" (eat a good fish)
omekapo.etymology: o moku e kala pona: kay(f)​to(t)ki(t)po(t)na(t)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​ngag(t)​vlim(p)​kay(f)​sna(f)​yup(f)​a(f), 'eat a good fish', wishing somebody well

ona.commentary: This word was coined in a poll in 2002. It replaced "iki", which was deemed too similar-sounding to "ike". Other options in the poll included "ipi" and "i".

open.commentary: Some proficient speakers use open as a preverb that means "start to," that goes along with the complimentary pini preverb "to stop"
open.definition: begin, start, open, turn on; beginning

owe.definition: totalitarian, Orwellian; of or relating to Big Brother from the book Nineteen Eighty-Four

pakala.definition: damaged, broken, botched, harmed, messed up; mistake
pakala.etymology: bagarap: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), accident; bugger up: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), bugger up

pake.definition: stop, cease, halt; to block the way, to interrupt; to prevent

pali.definition: work, activity; create, build, design; put effort toward, take action on

palisa.definition: long and hard thing e.g. branch, pole, rod, stick, spine, mast

pan.definition: grains, starchy foods, baked goods e.g. rice, sorghum, bread, noodles, masa, porridge, injera
pan.etymology: pan: Romance, bread; パン (pan): pov(t)​luw(f)​mi(p)​vu!(b)​luf(p)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), bread; pão: Portuguese, bread

pana.definition: give, send, emit, provide, put, release
pana.etymology: panna: sul(b)​rad(b)​sib(f)​fuf(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), put, set, place; pana: Swahili, give to each other

penpo.commentary: Coined in reference to ma pona pi toki pona's "tenpo pi toki pona taso" event, shortening it to "tenpo penpo".
penpo.etymology: (pi) toki pona taso: kay(f)​to(t)ki(t)po(t)na(t)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​ngag(t)​vlim(p)​kay(f)​sna(f)​yup(f)​a(f), only toki pona

pi.commentary: The usage of "pi" to mean "of" (marking a possessor) is heavily discouraged nowadays, preferring it to only be used for regrouping within phrases.
pi.definition: (particle) [group the following words into one modifier for the previous word]

pika.definition: electric, electronic, conductive, mechanical, online; electricity, lightning, thunder, network
pika.etymology: ピカチュウ (Pikachū): pov(t)​luw(f)​mi(p)​vu!(b)​luf(p)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), Pikachū, an electric Pokémon

pilin.definition: experience e.g. emotion, feeling, touch; heart (physical or emotional)

pimeja.definition: dark, unlit; dark color, e.g. black, purple, brown

pini.commentary: Some proficient speakers use pini as a preverb that means "to stop," that goes along with the complimentary open preverb "start to"
pini.definition: finish, stop, prevent; close, disable, turn off; ended, past; edge, end, conclusion
pini.etymology: fini: fub(p)bap(p)bus(p)fuf(t)sol(t)bop(p)ga(f) gin(t)​vek(t)​bis(f)​sub(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), finished, completed; pinis: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), finish (perfective aspect); finish: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), finish

pipi.definition: insect, bug, spider, tiny crawling creature

poka.definition: hip, side; next to, nearby, vicinity

poki.commentary: poki is sometimes used as "category" or to express types of things. One example is roles or groups, in discord chat contexts
poki.definition: container e.g. bag, bowl, box, cup, cupboard, drawer, folder
poki.etymology: bokis: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), box, female genitalia (vulgar); box: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), box

pona.definition: positive quality, e.g. good, pleasant, helpful, friendly, useful, peaceful

powe.definition: unreal, false, untrue; pretend; deceive, trick

pu.commentary: For ways to buy a copy of the book, visit the official Toki Pona website.
pu.definition: interacting with the book Toki Pona: The Language of Good by Sonja Lang
pu.etymology: 樸 (pǔ): seb(t)pof(p)pas(f)pis(p)ga(f) lab(b)​lik(f)​pav(f)​mal(p)​fof(b)​bot(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), unworked wood, sincere, honest, inherent quality, simple; book: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), book

puwa.definition: fluffy, soft, squishy (something that can be compressed and will try to go back to its original shape)

sama.definition: same, similar, alike; (adjective) peer, fellow, each other; (preposition) similar to, same as
sama.etymology: sama: sul(b)​rad(b)​sib(f)​fuf(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), same; *samaz: Proto-Germanic, same, alike; sama: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), same; same: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), same

san.commentary:
More popular than the synonymous (and older) tuli.
san was also part of a set of 10 digit words created by jan Lenoka: lenke, jatu, ini, san, se, nun, loku, take, patu, kajo (0 through 9). All of these coinages except for san lack notability to be included in the main dictionary. They can be found in the sandbox.
san.etymology: 三 (san): pov(t)​luw(f)​mi(p)​vu!(b)​luf(p)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), (number) three; 三 (sāam): kay(f)​粵(f)​語(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), (number) three; 叁 (sāam): kay(f)​粵(f)​語(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), (number) three

seli.commentary: In pu, definitions of seli are described as adjectives. ku's pu corrections clarify that these refer to nouns instead.
seli.definition: hot, warm; heat, fire, flame; burn

selo.definition: outer layer, e.g. skin, peel, shell, bark; outer shape, outer form, boundary
selo.etymology: ŝelo: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), skin, peel; schale: pup(b)​seb(f)​val(f)​tep(p)​bof(b)​zhel(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), peel, husk, shell

seme.definition: (particle) [indicate a question by marking missing info in a sentence]; what, which, who

sewi.definition: up, top, above, highest part; divine, sacred, supernatural; awesome, inspiring, excelling

sijelo.definition: body, shape, physical state, torso, substance, form

sike.definition: circle, sphere, spiral, round thing e.g. ball, wheel; repeating thing e.g. cycle, orbit, loop

sin.commentary: In common usage (both before and after pu), "sin" and "namako" are separate words, each with their own meaning. In pu, they are considered synonyms. Those who consider them synonyms typically don't use "namako" at all, preferring "sin" in all circumstances.
sin.definition: new, fresh, update; repeat, do again

sinpin.definition: vertical surface e.g. wall, board; front of something e.g. face
sinpin.etymology: 前邊 (tsin bin): kay(f)​粵(f)​語(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), in front

sitelen.definition: image, picture, representation, symbol, mark, writing

sona.definition: knowledge, information, data; know, be skilled in, be wise about; (preverb) know how to

su.commentary: This word was originally coined in ku as a reserved word for jan Sonja's future use. It was redefined upon the release of the first su book, making its status as a ku word debatable.
su.definition: interacting with a book from the illustrated story book series that began with The Wonderful Wizard of Oz, produced by Sonja Lang

suli.definition: big, heavy, large, long, tall, wide; important, relevant

suno.definition: light, shine, glow, radiance; sun, light source; brightness

supa.definition: flat horizontal surface, especially to put or rest things on e.g. bed, floor, desk, plate, table, platform, stage
supa.etymology: surfaco: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), surface; surface: fub(p)bap(p)bus(p)fuf(t)sol(t)bop(p)ga(f) gin(t)​vek(t)​bis(f)​sub(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), surface; surface: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), surface

sutopatikuna.commentary: Coined by Alexandre Baudry in 2009 in response to jan Sonja coining "kijetesantakalu" as part of 2009's April Fools.
sutopatikuna.etymology: čudnovati kljunaš: Serbo-Croatian, platypus, (literally) strange beak

taki.definition: sticky, magnetic; bond, attract, attach, clip
taki.etymology: 탁 (tag): fos(f)​!ar(p)​faf(f)​sek(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), the sound of two magnets hitting each other (onomatopoeia)

taso.commentary: Some proficient speakers use taso as a connector between sentences (X taso Y), similar to "X, but Y," as though taso behaved like la grammatically.
taso.definition: only, exclusively; (particle) [marks a sentence as qualifying or contradictory], but, however
taso.etymology: tasol: kay(f)​tok(b)pi(b)sin(b)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), just, only, but, however; that’s all: kus(f)​lib(p)​sab(b)​tip(t)​bot(t)​vev(f)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), that’s all

tawa.definition: motion, e.g. walking, shaking, flight, travel; (preposition) to, for, going to, from the perspective of

te.commentary: May be paired with "to", or used on its own. It is unclear how accepted either approach is among te / to users.

telo.definition: liquids e.g. water, gasoline, soda, lava, soup, oil, ink

tenpo.definition: time, event, situation, moment, period, duration

to.commentary: May be paired with "te", or used on its own. It is unclear how accepted either approach is among te / to users.

toki.definition: communicate, say, think; conversation, story; language

tomo.definition: indoor space or shelter e.g. room, building, home, tent, shack
tomo.etymology: domo: suf(t)​mef(t)​fik(p)​cub(b)​lov(f)​veb(t)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), house; dom: Polish, house; domus: Latin, house; δόμος: Ancient Greek, house

tonsi.commentary:
* - Broader in meaning, somewhat less commonly accepted.
Widely regarded in the community to be a crucial addition to toki pona. Occasionally referred to as an "honorary pu word" to highlight its status, or equated to a pu word outright.
tonsi.etymology: 同志 (tóngzhì): seb(t)pof(p)pas(f)pis(p)ga(f) lab(b)​lik(f)​pav(f)​mal(p)​fof(b)​bot(b)​san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​da(t)​grog(f)​kay(f)vlim(p)​ga(f)​vlim(p)​ga(f), comrade (same will/purpose), LGBT+

unpa.commentary: Also defined as "have marital relations with" in pu; removed due to potential confusion.

usawi.commentary: Originally, usawi also included "technology so complex it's impossible to tell apart from magic" in its meaning, but this meaning has been deprecated by the creator.
usawi.definition: magic, sorcery; enchant; magical, supernatural, occult, incomprehensible

uta.commentary: The dot in the "uta" sitelen pona is to distinguish luka-uta from moku.

utala.definition: fight, compete, battle; competition, challenge; struggle, strive

wa.commentary: Sometimes analyzed as a variety of "a".

walo.definition: light-colored, white, pale, light gray, cream

wan.definition: (number) one; singular; combine, join, mix, fuse

wasoweli.commentary: First used as the name for a species in a mod for Caves of Qud created by akesi kon Nalasuni. Later appeared in ku as exclusively part of a translation for "penguin".
wasoweli.definition: animal with qualities of both waso and soweli
wasoweli.etymology: waso: kay(f)​to(t)ki(t)po(t)na(t)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​ngag(t)​vlim(p)​kay(f)​sna(f)​yup(f)​a(f), bird, flying creature; soweli: kay(f)​to(t)ki(t)po(t)na(t)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​ngag(t)​vlim(p)​kay(f)​sna(f)​yup(f)​a(f), land animal, fuzzy creature

wawa.definition: power, energy, strength; confident, intense, forceful; amazing, impressive

weka.definition: absent, away, distant; remove, get rid of

wekama.definition: leave and come back, be temporarily absent with the expectation of returning
wekama.etymology: weka kama: kay(f)​to(t)ki(t)po(t)na(t)san(t)​ap(t)​vlir(t)​sang(b)​es(p)​u(t)​vom(b)​ngo(p)​ngag(t)​vlim(p)​kay(f)​sna(f)​yup(f)​a(f), 'leave-arrive', to leave and come back

wile.definition: want, desire, wish, require; (preverb) want to

wuwojiti.commentary: May be seen not as a word in toki pona, but as a kind of memorisation tool in English to refer to the "banned" syllables. Occasionally extended to wuwojitinmanna to include the illegal consecutive nasal consonants.
wuwojiti.definition: to use one or more of the "banned" syllables wu, wo, ji, or ti; to break toki pona phonotactics

yupekosi.commentary: Coined as a random keystroke. It is presumed jan Sonja used "y" by mistake, but then made it part of the joke by adding "nobody knows how to pronounce the y".
yupekosi.definition: to behave like George Lucas and revise your old creative works and actually make them worse
